desc: MAPK3 (mitogen-activated protein kinase 3, also known as ERK1) is a mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase considered an effector kinase in the RAS/RAF/MEK/ERK pathway. This pathway is triggered by mitosis and differentiation factors as well as cytokines, resulting in MEK1/2-mediated phosphorylation of MAPK3, which induces its homodimerization and translocation to the nucleus where it phosphorylates target proteins (PMID: 9604935, 9166761, 17496918). MAPK3 targets include cytoskeletal molecules and nucleoporins, but foremost kinases and transcription factors with central roles in cell proliferation and survival, including include RSK (ribosomal S6 kinase) and MSK ( mitogen- and stress-activated protein kinases), MYC, c-FOS, ELK-1, ETS-1 and MITF (PMID: 25320010, 22569528). MAPK3 and its homolog, MAPK1 (ERK2), are essential for cell proliferation; they are ubiquitously and often simultaneously expressed, but evidence suggests they may have some distinct functions in specialized contexts (PMID: 23482492, 21248139, 17496918). MAPK3 is mutated at low frequency in various types of cancers. Inhibitors of MAPK1/3 are being explored as complementary and alternative options to RAF and MEK inhibition in cases of resistance or partial response (PMID: 25435214).

desc: MAPK3 encodes a serine/threonine kinase involved in the MAPK signaling pathway. Amplifications of MAPK3 are found in breast and prostate cancers, among others.
